eastwood drew up plans that would ensure

additionally safety goggles were off

hanging on the hood of a car is the most

kiwi zoe bell is a real-life stunt woman
who plays herself and while shooting a
film in lebanon tennessee her and her
two friends test drive a 1970 dodge
challenger the same type of car used in
the 1971 classic vanishing point belle
insists on playing a game called ship's
mast where she rides on the hood of a
challenger at high speeds holding onto
belts that are fastened to the car's
body her friends abernathy and kim are
hesitant but belle won't be deterred and
as the car is whipping down the winding
roads of lebanon she climbs out of the
passenger side window and hangs from the
car's hood shouting with excitement the
fun quickly turns to terror as their
stalker stuntman mike played by kurt
russell catches up with belle and her
friends and tries to use his dodge
charger to run their challenger off the
road smashing into it repeatedly
oh
tarantino had been so impressed with
belle after she worked as uma thurman
stunt double and kill bill that he
decided to cast her in the leading role
in death proof belle insisted on pulling
off this dangerous stunt without a
double even though tarantino was
hesitant at first now that belle was a
main character and all it didn't take
much convincing though and the two
pulled one off as the best car chases in
decades bell admitted in an interview
that there was no double no cgi and that
it's all practical and you're seeing
that the person crying is the same one
who's falling off the car and that's a
perfect example of the reason people
have such a visceral response to that
sequence
mall pole slide jackie chan police story
jackie chan wrote directed starred and
performed his own stunts in the 1985
action comedy police story it's the tale
of detective kakui who must protect a
female witness from the hong kong drug
lord she once worked for kakui helps
arrest the drug lord but is then forced
to clear his name after being accused of
murder the film is loaded with
large-scale action sequences like a car
chase through a shanty town and a scene
where chan dangles from a seating
double-decker bus but the most notable
stunt and arguably one of the greatest
stunts in action cinema history is the
mall pole slide performed by chan
towards the end of the film chan's
character is chasing and fighting
criminals in a shopping mall which
culminates in him having to jump from a
high level onto a metal pole and slide
down several stories look i know it
doesn't sound as crazy as hanging from a
plane or from the hood of a challenger
but this stunt almost cost chan his life
just the jump from the railing to the
pole was dangerous enough if chan failed
to properly grab the pole he risked a
long fall to the ground below and there
was no wire or safety net involved
additionally the pole itself was
surrounded by decorative lights that
chan was meant to break while sliding
down
chan was concerned that he could get
shocked by the bursting electrical
lights but he was assured that they'd be
switched off if anything went wrong
despite precautions an error with the
lighting caused the pole to be heated to
a high temperature
chan managed to latch onto the burning
hot pole and slide down to safety
without loosening his grip but he
suffered second-degree burns on his
hands still this didn't stop him from
running off to shoot scenes from the
film heart of dragon in the same day
what a legend

running from the boulder harrison ford
raiders of the lost ark
next up is the iconic running from the
boulder stunt in raiders of the lost ark
harrison ford plays dr indiana jones a
renowned archaeologist who is hired by
the us government to find the ark of the
covenant which is believed to still hold
the ten commandments indiana and his
ex-lover marion must stop the nazis from
finding the ark first and in doing so
escape various close calls like a giant
boulder that comes very close to
flattening indiana like a pancake though
i'm sure the average person is familiar
with this sequence it's been parodied
countless times in popular culture just
don't think most people realize just how
dangerous this stunt was for ford
director steven spielberg later admitted
that he was an idiot for letting ford
perform this stunt his words not ours
but due to the nature of the scene ford
had to run directly towards the camera
as the giant rock followed after him
using a double would have made this shot
incredibly difficult they would have had
to have held their head down to hide the
fact that they aren't forward also keep
in mind that this was 1981 so no cgi or
fancy technology to rely on though the
boulder wasn't an actual boulder
obviously it was still 12 feet tall and
weighed 300 pounds it could have easily
done bodily harm to ford had he tripped
or just simply not outrun it he would
have died by the boulder or
embarrassment it took ten nail-biting
takes for spielberg to be satisfied
which meant ten close calls for ford

roger ebert once wrote of buster
keaton's extraordinary period from 1920
to 1929 in which he worked without
interruption and became one of the
greatest actor directors in the history
of the movies orson welles even called
keaton a supreme artist and one of the
most beautiful people who was ever
photographed yes keaton was an
extraordinary talent with a career that
lasted well into the 60s but he also
didn't make it past the shooting of the
silent film steamboat bill jr in 1928
and we can blame that on the house full
stunt in which a 4 000 pound front side
of a house falls forward and narrowly
misses keaton thanks to a perfectly
placed attic window
in the film a tornado wreaks havoc on a
small town and keaton's character
william canfield jr is caught in the
middle of it he gets tossed around by
the harsh winds but manages to stand and
catch his balance just before the heavy
house collapses around him keaton
remains standing avoiding certain injury
and possible death by only a few inches
it goes without saying but there were no
special effects back then no cgi
heck there weren't even sounds on film
yet keaton had to stand on a very
precise mark in order for this stunt to
work no room for error according to
hollywood legend keaton's shoes were
nailed down on his mark so he wouldn't
be tempted to move
keaton later recalled that crew members
were praying during this scene and the
cameraman had to look away as the shot
rolled
this stunt has been imitated countless
times since the release of steamboat
bill jr hopefully in a somewhat safer
manner

tom cruise mission impossible fall out
last but not least we circle back to tom
cruise this time he's dangling from and
piloting a helicopter in mission
impossible fallout the sixth installment
in the series cruz returns is ethan hunt
who joins forces with a cia assassin
named august walker or if you're
american argus walker to prevent an epic
disaster involving plutonium like every
mi movie the stakes get higher the
action gets more intense and cruz pulls
off some death-defying stunt that leaves
audiences stunned for this one it's as
if cruz saw statham and crank and
thought to himself hey
i can do that i'll even one-up him by
also flying the helicopter myself and
that's exactly what he did for the first
part of this sequence cruz hangs from
the landing skids of a helicopter as it
tows a cargo load below 1200 feet up in
the air at one point he slips and falls
roughly 40 feet landing hard on the
cargo load as it dangles though crews
had safety harnesses on the fall was
real and wanted the landing to be hard
so it looked authentic ugh i flinched
when i saw it
during one take crews missed the cargo
load and cast members panicked thinking
that he'd fallen to his death in an
interview rebecca ferguson expressed
that she heard herself scream and
actually thought he fell
she added that there was an audible gas
from the crowd that's just the half of
it cruz then flew the helicopter through
the mountains at low altitude for a
chase scene one that required him
getting dangerously close to another
helicopter
the crew developed special camera rigs
that face the inside of the helicopter
ensuring viewers that it was really
crews and crews alone piloting the actor
spent three months at a helicopter
school in texas in order to gain these
skills needed to pull off this stunt
which included a corkscrew nose dive one
of the most dangerous maneuvers a pilot
could attempt and there you have it our
picks for the most dangerous stunts by
real actors as always we couldn't
include every death defying feat that
fits the bill but there are plenty more
episodes of rt essentials coming your
way so i'm sure we'll get there
